The Man: Richard C. Young
Often called in by America's wealthiest families to do a little "repair work" on portfolios that have lost a couple or ten million.
Personally wealthy. "Why would you take advice from someone who had made less money than you have?"
Lives frugally. Runs or walks 5 miles a day. Highly disciplined about what he eats. Married 37 years with two grown children and four grandchildren. His few extravagances include a tendency to buy 30 or 40 jazz CDs at a clip.
Skeptical. "If my own mother tells me the time, I check my watch."
Has never biked through the Andes on his Harley, but he and his wife want to go. "When you travel a country on a Hog, folks make a point of talking to you. That's how you come up with great investments. You don't find them on a computer screen on Wall Street. Plus, it's major fun."
Rarely gives interviews. Reporters declare him "curmudgeonly" but he despises the media circus. "Everyone's got an angle they're trying to push. Even the journalists. I don't have an angle. I just want top returns without risk to principal. Not much of a story there."
Devoted follower of Graham and Dodd, the founding fathers of financial analysis. Graham's definition of an investment is taped to Young's computer. It says, "An investment operation is one which, upon thorough analysis, promises safety of principal and satisfactory return. Operations not meeting these requirements are speculative." Young's Intelligence Report is so named as a tip-of-the-hat to Graham's most important work, The Intelligent Investor.
Gave up a career on Wall Street as one of its most respected analysts and traders. "In the end, the herd mentality is too strong to resist. Living in the countryside, I can maintain my independence of outlook and help the people I admire--individual investors."
Earned his B.S. in investments from Babson College, where he has served as investment advisor to the Board of Trustees.
His first job was as a Wall Street runner, earning $60 a week.
Lost $5,000 once. "It wasn't an investment. It was a speculation." That was the first and last time in over 36 years of investing that he became confused about the difference.
Sees Young's Intelligence Report as his life-work. "I can make a real, lasting difference to so many private investors this way. I know that all the work that goes in is worthwhile, because subscribers tell me so." Indeed, it is a rare occurrence for a subscriber to drop off the rolls.
Credentials: Keynote speaker at prestigious investment conferences. ("I try to limit my appearances to once-a-decade. More often could give the wrong impression.") Best-selling author of Richard C. Young's Financial Armadillo Strategy, hailed as "required reading" by the press. The Professional Investor said the book "surpasses anything written on personal finances for the past 18 years."


If  you didn’t double, triple or quadruple  your money in the last 5 years in the great bull market in things—commodities  like gold, copper, steel, coal, uranium, oil or natural gas, please read every  word of this urgent report.
Indeed,  if you are not sitting down and ready to take notes right now, PLEASE LAY THIS  REPORT ASIDE until this evening, when you can review it carefully and make some  very important decisions.
You  may feel you missed out on the great commodities bull market of the last 4  years and that, in any case, commodities are too risky for a conservative  investor like you.
But  you are mistaken on both counts.
And  in fact a commodity laggard—agriculture—is just beginning its amazing bull run.
Best  of all, new ETF funds make investing in commodities as diverse as biofuels,  timber or corn a snap.
Time  To Take Another
Bite  of The Apple
Allow  me to introduce myself.
My  name is Dick Young and I would like to tell you exactly how to achieve your most ambitious financial goals  in the next 36 months, and do it in natural resource stocks.
This  is a very practical guide.  I’m  going to lay out as much of my plan as possible in the next few pages and then  I’m going to show you what first steps you must take.  To make sure we get the job DONE, I’m going to stick with  you FOR THE WHOLE YEAR.
By  that time, you could be well on your way to achieving your goals. 
Well  on your way to reaching your dreams without EVER, even for one second, becoming  a speculator.
And  you will have done it by investing conservatively in…commodity stocks.
One  Thing I Do Require
I’ve  already said I don’t need you to be a speculator.  In truth, risk-takers appall me.  I don’t make friends with traders and they consider me a  terrible stick-in-the-mud.
But  the very thought of losing a dollar on  an investment fills me with dread.   Once, when I was a young Wall Street runner in the ‘60s, I lost $5,000  on a speculation.  That experience  made me so physically sick, I  made a solemn vow never to let it happen again.
And  it hasn’t.
No  Dreamers, Please
I have put a lifetime of study into success.  Success of every stripe.
What,  for example, makes the Rolling Stones successful?  That is not a question most investment advisors would think  to ask, is it?  The answer in The  Stones’ case is Andrew Oldham, the man who literally locked Jagger and Richards  in his kitchen to force them to write their own songs.
In  a world of one-hit wonders, the Stones keep rolling, keep on message, and just  get more and more successful.
That’s  how I work and that is how I expect you to work with me.  Success compounds success—that’s what I have learned over the last 35 years of  professional investing.

Step One: The Great Sugar Rush
 
In 1974, the price of sugar was 66  cents.  Then it collapsed to almost  2 cents in 1985.  For the next  decade, sugar was stuck at a dime or less.
In  the last few months, the price of sugar has doubled—and the value of a white  sugar futures contract has quadrupled.
This  breakout has been two decades in the making:

First, Brazil got smart and decided to dominate sugar  production while stabilizing prices by diverting all over-supply into ethanol.


Meanwhile, sugar demand rose 63% in the last 20 years,  largely driven by huge increases in consumption in Asia.


And supply has shrunk in Europe, Africa, even Asia.  Exports of sugar from the EU, for example, have collapsed from 7 million tonnes  a year in 2005 to less than one million  in 2007.


And finally, oil prices went stratospheric—and remain  so high, sugar-based ethanol prices are up over 250% since mid 2004!

The case for sugar  is compelling today, but I don’t want  you running around out there trying to buy sugar futures!  Employ a new ETF fund to do that for  you.  The one I have selected works  on a formula that cushions the effect of monthly contracts rolling at very  different prices.  





Shares of the top agriculture and  energy futures exchange, Intercontinental Exchange, (ICE) have doubled in the  last year as the second round in the commodities super-cycle gets under way.


Unless you have a  cast-iron stomach, you need that.
If sugar has been  so low, so long, isn’t a collapse possible again?  Yes—if Asia stops growing.  Yes—if the price of a gallon of gas goes back to 33  cents.  
Those are odds I  find very acceptable.

Step Two: Start Your Geiger
        Counters
 
Get A Grip On The New
        Reality
If you really, truly
        want to make remarkably safe, fast profits--not just dream about it, but really
        DO IT--then you must come to grips with
        the central theme of our time: we are at war. A world
        war. It is a war, like all wars, of Havenots against Haves. The difference between the
        Haves and Have-nots is not difficult to define. The average wage of a Chinese
        laborer, gluing MacDonald's Happy Meal toys together in suffocating labor
        camps, is 60 cents an hour. A few hours away, in Singapore or Australia, the
        average wage is
        $6.70 an hour.
Or consider Central
        America. The average Nicaraguan makes $2,400 a year. A few miles across the
        jungle, a Costa Rican makes $10,100.
Uranium is one
        commodity the Havenots desperately want (there are many others, as we shall
        see, and each
        presents a stunning investment opportunity). Uranium also happens to be one
        commodity that North America is abundantly rich in.
To have, in investment
        terms, is to have natural resources--commodities in desperate demand.
So this is where you
        must begin. And
        uranium is your very first step in our million
        dollar quest.
The Weakest Link
That pound of
        yellowcake valued at $9 before 9/11, is now worth $95. In 1979, when
        America was still building nuclear reactors and the arms race was in full
        swing, uranium hit $43 a pound--so until recently, it has been a long bear market.
But a uranium shortage of huge magnitude is developing so quickly that many of the earth's most critical nuclear power plants could face the risk of imminent SHUTDOWN.  
Nearly 200 million
        pounds of uranium is needed this year to keep the lights on in France, China,
        the U.K. and U.S.A. But only 100 million pounds will be mined.
And meanwhile, China is
        building FORTY new reactors!
And with reactor
        shut-downs come blackouts, a global economic seizure, political unrest, and
        oil prices at home you
        don't even want to think about!
Uranium prices,

        before 9/11,

        Colgate-Palmolive.

The first step is to buy a small stake in this North American uranium mine. This stock is up over 507% in the past three years, so we're off to a good start in our million dollar quest.

One driver of this Uranium Rush is uncertainty over oil prices. So let's see how we can factor oil into our own race for safe, fast profits.

Now let's look at oil,

You've heard it said that the world is running out of oil and that's why it's costing more. This is balderdash.

        cutting back.
But still, prices are
        up from about $20 a barrel on 9/11 to around $60 a barrel today. So: why? Because oil has
        become the ultimate weapon of Havenot revenge.
If you want to see
        this dirty bomb used at its cruelest, consider what "Father Joseph" Putin did
        in February 2004. He simply cut off the gas pipelines to Belarus. It was
        exactly what it appeared
        to be--an act of terrorism--a guerrilla maneuver in the greater
        World War III action.
Oil Stocks: A Slow
        Swim Across A Shark Tank
As investors, then,
        we need to be very careful about using oil in
        our program to make a million dollars. We must not make the mistake of buying it

We're not running out any time
        soon--and it isn't even going

        reflection of how it is being used as
        a weapon. After all, Saudi oil costs just $3 a barrel. Call the other $50 or

Step Four: Considering the Alternatives
 
Every investor needs to understand--and invest maybe just a little--in alternative energy. This might mean wind power (General Electric, with its turbines, is the way to go here), biorefineries or ethanol.
But my money's on coal.
Yes--coal.
Here at Young's Intelligence Report, we've doubled our money in coal stocks just in the last year, but we very well could double that double in the next year. Here's why.
A new process takes low-grade, water-logged, $6-a-ton Western U.S. coal, and converts into a clean liquid fuel worth the equivalent of $60 a barrel.
The process is expensive but several factors make K-fuel, as it's called, work:
It cuts our dependency. The American west sits atop a larger store of energy than Saudi Arabia. It's simply in the form of coal, not oil. Some of the coal is high quality and where it is, you should invest. No less than 140 new coal-fired power plants are about to be built.  This is more than at any time since the 1950s. Coal is the new favorite alternative to oil. Here at Young's Intelligence Report we've been getting fat on a Canadian coal trust that produces super high-grade coal and returns the profits to us in the form of a 11.3% yield. Very nice.
It's clean. Coal's big drawback has always been that it burns dirty. Clean it up, convert it into liquid diesel, and you've turned low-grade coal you'd otherwise discard in slag heaps into a $2-a-gallon at the pump high-test. Pure alchemy.
It's making early investors rich. Call it the Spindletop Effect. The U.S. company that's leading the K-fuel revolution is up 73% in the last three years.  But at no point in the past 3 years would I have recommended it except as a speculation. And Sasol, the South African blue chip, has created a $20 billion business out of converting low-grade coal to diesel.  The fact that Sasol is also up 148% in three years tells you: the clean coal solution is for real.

But they are ruinous for investors who need to plan for their retirement.

But if you had shut your ears to what you were being told about growth stocks and, instead, invested in small value stocks, your dollar would have blossomed to $16,027.
These numbers, supplied by the research firm Ibbotson Associates, are irrefutable, but behind the numbers lurks a real tragic story.
Why They Call It Burn Rate

Unable to hold on during wild whipsaws, they sell and buy a different growth stock, become traders and gamblers instead of long-term wealth-builders. If there are any winnings, they are swallowed in taxes and commissions, leaving crumbs for their retirement. 
In short, your children will curse the day you became a growth investor.

Step Five: Should You Buy Gold Now?
 
Between 1971 and 1974, the price of oil went from $1.65 a barrel to $9.76--a 592% increase.
It was a period that looks in retrospect like the first rumblings of today's roaring World War III. Oil fields were being nationalized, America was loathed by the Havenots and global tribalism was rampant.
What happened to gold? Gold prices also soared. The ounce of gold worth $43.63 in 1971 was worth $186.50 four years later--a 427% increase. 
On 9/11, the price of oil was $26 and gold was $271. Since then, oil prices are up 130% and gold is up 153%.
So, again, a reasonably close correlation, yes?
I'd like to compare oil and gold prices because this approach sidesteps the emotional issues that can cloud our thinking about gold. We can put the case for gold simply in terms of oil. If you believe oil prices are headed back towards $26 a barrel, whatever you do, don't buy gold.
But if you believe oil prices could hit $100 a barrel, mortgage the farm and load up on gold--it'll be the smartest investment move of your life.

Step Six: How Copper Got Golden

Right now, the world has three days of copper reserves. 
This is not a dangerous situation. It is catastrophic.
But it is eerily familiar to you, if you have read carefully everything I have told you about oil, gas and gold. A glut triggers infrastructure neglect, which is followed by an economic boom of such force the supply-demand see-saw breaks. Countries with the commodity talk of nationalism, which drives prices to speculative heights.
